Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 10:14AM - edited Sep 23, 2011 10:16AM by cycle-path By the time you read this you'll already have had the tests, but you'll certainly have others in your life so it's worth a discussion. Let's talk about modesty. I'm all for modesty in public, but let's face it -- these doctors and technicians have seen the breasts and other so-called private parts of thousands, maybe tens of thousands of women. Looking at your breast is, to them, the same as looking at your arm. It's just not special or different to them. When they're looking at you they're not looking at something private, they're looking at what they need to look at to help you. Try to keep this in mind during your examinations. "Modesty" doesn't come into it - modesty is about showing and covering what's appropriate to show or cover in a particular situation. It's appropriate to cover up in your daily life, but "appropriateness" goes out the window when a medical examination is going on. The person examining you has seen many thousands of body parts and is not thinking about your body parts in any sort of improper way. Keep this in mind and try to relax. You'll be happier, be more comfortable, and may even get better results if you can be relaxed.

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2011 10:47AM cycle-path wrote: "If it is/was just an infection, why do I still have this 3+ inch diameter pink sensitive patch of skin on my breast after taking a 10 day course of strong antibiotics?" Because many of the organisms that cause human infections have become resistant to antibiotics. It may well take more, or probably different, antibiotics to clear it up. The fact that it became more sore after three days off the antibiotic is clearly indicative of an antibiotic-resistant infection. Keep after it! It could take many days of several more antibiotics before the infection is beaten down.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2011 09:17PM cycle-path wrote: It sounds as though your doctors believe your tumor is non-invasive, which is good. As far as feeling strong and healthy, I think breast cancer only makes people feel ill when they are in very late stages. I never felt different, and I don't recall hearing anyone else (other than late stage people or those in chemo, etc.) say they felt ill. Estrogen negative: the reason that's not so good is that there are fewer treatments available. The standard treatment for these non-invasive tumors is lumpectomy, radiation, and Tamoxifen, but Tamoxifen is only effective against the estrogen-positive tumors, or so I understand.  It's true the cancer could come back after lumpectomy because of a small amount of tissue left. That's why they do radiation -- to fry any stray cancer cells after the surgery. The bigger problem is this: once you've had breast cancer, any kind of breast cancer, you're identified as being at risk for getting it again. It's sort of like kidney stones -- once you've had one kidney stone you're identified as a "stone former" and you're more likely to get another one than the person next door who's never had a stone. I hope that helps explain things a little. It sounds to me as though your situation is pretty good, since you apparently have a non-invasive cancer. You'll get through this and in the end you'll be fine!

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2011 12:02PM - edited Aug 24, 2011 12:17PM by cycle-path Mods, I know there is IORT info on the site, but why not talk about it (or at least link to it) on the Internal Radiation page, for example? It seems a little silly to make it part of the External Radiation section, doesn't it? Further: some of the info on the IORT page is incorrect. "all the doctors and nurses must leave the room while intraoperative radiation is delivered." Not true, because some IORT is delivered via X-ray and personnel need only be shielded as for a normal X-ray. "Using intraoperative radiation for internal radiation is very new. Only small studies with short follow-ups have been done so far." Not true -- IORT has been available since 1918. "Intraoperative internal radiation hasn't been compared to the standard of care: whole-breast radiation after lumpectomy." Untrue.   "It's very expensive to have a radiation machine and proper shielding in an operating room. Most radiation therapy departments are far away from the operating rooms, so the equipment can't be shared or moved." While it's true that it's expensive to have this, it's also not necessary because some IORT machines use Xray only and no shielding is required in the OR. Also, some IORT machines are highly portable. The article is out of date and appears to have been written by a MO who is opposed to the use of IORT (probably for personal financial reasons). An updated and much less biased article should be provided, but either way there should be links!

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 01:13PM cycle-path wrote: I had this after my lumpectomy and SNB as well but it went away 100% within 3 or 4 weeks. I found these exercises: http://www.cancer.org/Cancer/BreastCancer/MoreInformation/exercises-after-breast-surgery and did them pretty faithfully. One thing I've suggested to a few women is this: stand in the middle of an interior doorway as though you're walking through it. Move your non-surgical side next to the door jamb and reach up as far as you can with your non-surgical hand. Get someone to mark the highest point you can reach.  Then turn around and spider-walk up the door jamb with your surgical side. See how far you can go, marking the highest point if you wish. Do this a few times every day. The goal is to get to the same height as on the non-surgical side.

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2011 04:54PM cycle-path wrote: I wasn't tested for HER2, but when I got my biopsy reports the doctor told me that ER+ and PR+ were good. She said that tumors that have good hormone receptors are those that haven't morphed too much. Basically cancer cells are normal cells that have started to morph into something else, and when they morph too much they eventually stop looking and behaving like regular cells. The ER- and PR- cells are ones that have less resemblance to normal cells. As I say, that's what my doc told me. From a practical and treatment standpoint, the good thing about ER+ and HER2+ is that there are more drug therapies for those of us with those outcomes, such as Tamoxifen and Herceptin.

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2011 04:01PM - edited Aug 20, 2011 08:29PM by cycle-path I am very sorry for anyone who was hurt by the reaction or inaction of someone else. Probably all of us have at least been disappointed in some way by at least one person's reaction. In the defense of these people, though, I have to say I think it's hard to know how to react. Recently I met someone who mentioned he had cancer. I was about to ask him about it but the conversation was interrupted and I didn't get the chance. A few days later I asked someone else who knows him what kind of cancer he has and what's going on, and she said she didn't know because she thought it was "rude" to ask him about it. I can think of people I know who got cancer and I never really talked to them about it. I wasn't sure what to ask about. Sometimes I was afraid they'd get too emotional, sometimes I thought I was intruding.   I think it's hard to know how to react. I had DCIS, and my attitude is that it's pretty much a done deal for me -- I need to be watchful for the rest of my life, but that's it. But a lot of people I see ask me, in an ominous way, "How ARE you!???!" Huh? I'm fine! How are YOU? I completely accept what they're doing and understand it, but I find it slightly annoying. And I almost wish I'd never told them. I think it's hard to know how to react. There was a woman on the boards a few weeks ago who wanted to develop a line of Kick-Axx Cancer Cards. Some people liked the idea, others were horrified. She had chosen one way to react that IMO would work for some people but not for others. It's absolutely reasonable to be disappointed in your friends or angry with them. You're free to react to their non-reaction in any way, and if you're hurt, it's a real hurt. I don't really intend to defent them. But I think they're grappling (poorly) with something that's very hard to figure out. They're not mind-readers and they don't know what you need. It's likely that, in fear of doing the wrong thing, they do nothing. It's just hard to know how to react!

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2012 02:26PM - edited Jan 18, 2012 05:32PM by cycle-path Robin, I'd say that your case is different. You have a complex cyst, which is apparently being aspirated for two reasons -- for comfort (because these things can eventually become painful), and to absolutely rule out cancer. Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 07:15PM cycle-path wrote: katiebug, there are two more options your doctor didn't tell you about. One is Partial Breast Irradiation (PBI), which is also referred to by the name of the device used -- Mammosite, Savi, and Contura are the most common. With PBI, you have a lumpectomy and a temporary balloon-like catheter is put into your breast. For 5 days after the surgery you get radiation via the catheter twice a day -- ten doses.  The other option you weren't told about is Intraoperative Radiation Therapy (IORT). With IORT, which is what I had, the catheter is placed inside the tumor cavity during surgery and a single dose of radiation is delivered right at the tumor site immediately. Then the catheter is removed, the wound is closed, and you're done. IORT is the greatest thing ever for DCIS patients, but the disadvantage to it is that it isn't available everywhere and you'd probably have to change doctors to get it. You can get it at Mass General in Boston.  www.massgeneral.org/radiationo...  www.breastcanceriort.org/  Some doctors will tell you that these procedures are "experimental" or other derogatory things, but the truth is that doctors don't make as much money doing these types of radiation and that's why they don't like it. If you don't like the options you were given, check out these other two. I don't think you'll be sorry. Long story, but I fought like the dickens to be able to get IORT and it was so worth it!

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 04:53PM cycle-path wrote: Cancer in the sister or sisters of grandmothers is not considered to be significant family history. Significant family history is parent, sibling, or child. So as far as family history goes, you're not at greater risk than average.  As far as I know, the description of 3 x 1 cm and location of 10 o'clock have no significance. Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2011 09:44AM cycle-path wrote: One thing I noticed on the path report from my lumpectomy was that the pathologist tells exactly what was found on all parts of the tissue removed. Upon removal, apparently the various sides of the tissue are stained different colors. Let's say the "north" side is blue, the east is red, the west is yellow, and the south is green. So on the path report it says the blue and yellow sides had good clear margins, the red side was clear but there was some ADH left, the green side was not clear.  From this, apparently the doc knows s/he has to get a little more tissue on the east side and maybe a fair amount more on the south side.  Therefore, when they go back in they're not just hacking away -- they know what they have to do and where, and that's why they almost always get clear margins the second time.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 08:59AM cycle-path wrote: Sue, the reason I asked about being in the UK is that most of the posters here are American and we tend to give American-style advice. But the medical system in the UK is different, as many of us here know, and you don't have some of the choices we have. (OTOH you probably don't have to worry about losing your home and your life savings due to medical expenses....) MRI is a pretty common part of the diagnostic process in the US but may not be elsewhere. MRI can be very useful but it can also show a lot of false positives. One of my doctors told me recently that she thinks breast MRIs are sort of a scam, and while I don't think too many doctors would agree with her I can see her point. As I understand it, the purpose of a breast MRI is to see if there are additional lesions beyond the ones found with other methods (mammogram, ultrasound). But as I said, MRI tends to find benign lesions, which apparently leads to biopsies of normal tissue and a lot of expense and worry for patients. So, in the UK, where medical costs are more controlled, maybe it's just not used much.  You might want to start another topic with something about the UK in the title of the post if you want to get input from other ladies in the UK. About "removing the lump for biopsy." Some surgeons do what's called an excisional biopsy, which is basically the same as a lumpectomy. It's not uncommon. Most biopsies are just a sample of the tissue, but for one reason or another sometimes the entire lump is removed. I don't know the logic of doing one versus the other, but perhaps someone else will chime in and explain that. After the excisional biopsy the tissue will be sent for pathological examination to find out what it is. But the doctor may have an idea, once he sees the tissue, of what's going on. Pathology will give him the final answer but sometimes the appearance tells a lot. When you have the biopsy you might want to ask how and when you will receive the pathology results. It's easier to wait when you know how long the wait will be.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 02:40AM cycle-path wrote: "From what I've read, I'm glad that I'm having a SNB rather than ALND. At this point, that's my preference." The SNB and ALND are done for 2 different reasons. The SNB is diagnostic: it's used to determine whether the cancer has spread outside the breast. The ALND is therapeutic: nodes that are cancerous, or are believed to be cancerous, are removed as part of the breast cancer treatment. There's some controversy associated with ALND. While it was a standard treatment until pretty recently, some studies last year said that it wasn't worthwhile. But rather than tell you about that, perhaps you'd prefer to read this article:  http://bioblog.biotunes.org/bioblog/2011/03/03/axillary-lymph-node-dissection-will-hopefully-soon-be-a-thing-of-the-past/

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 02:36AM - edited Dec 31, 2011 02:36AM by cycle-path I think it's important to understand the PURPOSE of the birads numbering. Birads was developed as a way for radiologists to communicate their mammo findings in a uniform and standard way so that when records went from doctor to doctor and from hospital to hospital, everyone looking at the findings could understand them. Birads was never intended to predict cancer. When you get a mammo, what they're trying to "prove" is that you don't have cancer or anything else of concern. When the Birads score is high, the radiologist is saying, "What I've seen on the mammo makes it impossible for me to rule out cancer (or another condition of concern)."  Therefore, when you get a high Birads score (generally meaning a 4 or 5) the next step is to perform one or more other procedures that could rule out cancer, such as a biopsy.  So don't get too excited about the Birads score -- it's really a tool for communication between doctors and a higher number just means more tests are needed. If no one has contacted you to schedule additional testing, be sure you do so yourself! You've done the first part -- you've apparently had your annual mammo -- but your job isn't done. Make sure the followup testing is done soon. And let us know what happens!

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 09:20PM cycle-path wrote: Trish, I've been thinking about your post all day. As you may have already discovered, 90% of instances of nipple discharge are due to something other than cancer. So while it's not impossible that you have some sort of cancer, it's not terribly likely.  The thing I keep coming back to is the odor of the discharge, which makes me think of infection. Infections are often extremely malodorous, especially when the infection has no where to go.  Your aunt thinks Augmentin would have cleared up any breast infection, but that doesn't seem correct to me. Augmentin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, but as we know many bacteria these days have become antibiotic resistant. If you have a breast infection, there's no reason to think it's not resistant to Augmentin. And as shelley said above, it could be something like MRSA, which can't be treated with Augmentin.  Here's an article about Mammary Duct Ectasia. Here's an article about Periductal Mastitis.  If you look at this page, it indicates that a discharge that's sticky and purulent is generally not cancer.   That being said, even if it's not cancer doesn't mean it's not serious. If you really can't go to a doc until 2012, call tomorrow and get an appointment for the earliest day and time available in 2012.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2012 03:55AM cycle-path wrote: Although you won't get any definitive answers to your issues on the internet, here are some things to consider: 1) statistically, exposure to hormones does increase the risk of breast cancer over your lifetime. birth control pills, Mirena, or (when you get older) hormone replacement all increase your risk. Now, many women use hormonal birth control for years, even decades, and never get breast cancer. So hormone exposure doesn't cause cancer per se -- it just increases the statistical risk over your lifetime. 2) Women, particularly those exposed to hormones, get lots of lumpy bumpy things in their breasts that are not cancer. These things should always be checked out, but most of them are not cancer.  3) Note that while hormones increase lifetime risk, they increase risk of non-cancerous lumpy-bumpies while they're being taken.  4) Lumps that feel non-mobile to the layperson are often classified as mobile by a medical professional. 5) While you're not too young to have breast cancer, your age is in your favor. It's pretty rare to get BC in your twenties. IMO you should definitely follow up on the recommended tests and such, but the odds are very much on your side.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2011 01:14AM cycle-path wrote: Lisa, what kind of work do you do? I think the answer depends on whether there's a physical component to your work.  I'll assume, though, that you have a desk job with no physical component. In my personal experience, the thing that requires the most recovery time is the Sentinel Node Biopsy. There's some discomfort involved with that, for a while, and the use of that arm is somewhat limited for a few weeks.  I didn't find the lumpectomy itself to be particularly problematic, certainly less so than the SNB. As far as the IORT radiation, it does cause some fatigue for 3 1/2 or 4 weeks. You might want to try to leave work early for a few weeks if you can. If you can't, plan to take it VERY easy when you get home in the evening. Let someone else do the grocery shopping, meal preparation, etc. I don't work, but I believe I could have worked soon after my lumpectomy/SNB/IORT. But I know I would have been very wiped out when I came home and would have wanted someone to bring me dinner so I could eat and go straight to bed.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2011 05:35PM cycle-path wrote: Sadly, none of us are, as far as I know, doctors. We have no training in reading mammos or ultrasounds or anything else. And even if we did, we really couldn't tell you anything based on your description of what the film looked like to YOU. If your doctor feels there was something that was a concern, she will refer you for a biopsy. If she thinks it's just some sort of odd doo-dad ("a technical term"), she will not. If you're not sure what she thought, call the office and ask if you're being referred for a biopsy. If you're not being sent for a biopsy, ask why not. They owe you a clear explanation of that. As I say, we really can't help you analyze a scan. But we can help you learn what questions to ask and stuff like that.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2011 07:01AM - edited Jun 12, 2011 07:04AM by cycle-path I almost had it but ended up with IORT instead. If you're a candidate for one you *should* be a candidate for the other. The reason I almost had it was that the IORT machine used by my doctor was not certified until the day after my lumpectomy. Therefore, I had the temporary balloon placed in my breast and was going to have SAVI but the doctor called and said the machine had been certified, so she removed the balloon and I had IORT instead. One of the biggest advantages to internal radiation, either IORT or SAVI/Mammosite/whatever is that you won't get burning on your skin. If you check out some of the threads here you'll find this was very bad for some women. Another big advantage is the reduced treatment time. I found the balloon very uncomfortable while it was in my breast, and I was unable to sleep much while it was in. However, I still would have chosen it over whole breast radiation. WBI scares me.  I urge you to check out IORT -- look at www.breastcanceriort.org/ and other sites -- and see what you think. IORT is not available in some states but if it's available near you, try to get it! You won't be sorry.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2011 10:02PM - edited Jul 19, 2011 01:54PM by cycle-path Yuelin, I had only a single rad treatment and no chemo, so I can't tell you how that will affect you. However, someone above said something like "there's no way this will fly with a new employer" and I must respectfully disagree. I have interviewed prospective employees for whom I would have cut off my left arm to get them to take a job because they were my "dream employee." If you decide your medical issues will affect your work, you need to give the prospective employer the opportunity to decide whether you're "worth it." You sound to me like a very motivated and conscientious employee, and I think you might have been one of those people for whom I would have cut off a limb. Consider telling them the whole story and let them decide. Let them know how much *you* want to work for *them.* You may be able to come to some kind of agreement that will make everyone happy.  Recently I saw a Dilbert cartoon that I should have saved. The pointy haired boss is interviewing a really rude guy. He decides to hire him, saying, "You must have awesome technical skills or else someone would have killed you by now." If you are one of those people with such awesome technical skills, an employer will put up with a LOT to nab you!

I think there are four main considerations, in no particular order: 1) the trauma Beesie mentions from false positives, 2) cost, 3) the potential for a misplaced sense of security from false negatives, and 4) the minor but real risk of radiation exposure from repeated mammograms. I'm not advocating for the new guidelines, but I also think that cost is only one factor among the reasons behind them.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2011 12:52PM cycle-path wrote: I agree with ej01 -- radiation is still generally recommended for DCIS. I know of no studies that have been done that show there's no benefit to radiation for women with DCIS, and the only way recommendations are developed is through completion of longitudinal studies.  There may be exceptions for very, very tiny DCIS tumors and rather elderly women, and I've seen discussions about whether radiation is indicated for women with multiple other health problems that could be worsened by radiation. But for garden-variety DCIS, radiation is still the standard at this time.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 07:34PM cycle-path wrote: Fran, I had something similar to Mammosite, called Intraoperative Radiation Therapy (IORT). It is only recommended for people over 50 who have single site, relatively small tumors, so it may not be for you. But if you fit that description I strongly urge you to look into it.  IORT is a breeze. The radiation is done *during* surgery so you are finished with everything in a single procedure. Trials have shown it to be as effective as partial breast irradiation. In general, surgeons who don't recommend it do so because they don't have access to it. But it's probably available somewhere near you.

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2011 06:02PM cycle-path wrote: The ladies above have given you good information. The surgeon (who should be willing to give you a copy of the pathology report from your biopsy) will, based on the pathology report, be able to make an educated guess about the size of the total tumor and the stage. It seems as though the surgeon's guess is correct most of the time but occasionally it's not. Based on that educated guess, and possibly some additional tests such as an MRI, the surgeon will recommend a course of action or a couple of different plans from which you might choose.  For example, in many cases a lumpectomy (usually with radiation) is sufficient. Sometimes a mastectomy is recommended, with or without radiation. Chemotherapy may also be "on the menu." My suggestion is this: if you can, take someone along with you to meet the surgeon and ask the other person to take notes. Sometimes one's head is spinning and it's difficult to absorb everything that's said. If that's not possible, try to jot down some notes yourself. The doc will probably draw some pictures and write a few things down but it's a good idea to do some of your own writing. Then when you get home, use your notes (and/or your friend's) and write down everything you remember. If you have questions about something, BCO is a good place to ask them.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 11:50AM cycle-path wrote: Regarding imaging: breast health imaging is generally done by mammo, U/S, or MRI. As I understand it, the mammo and the U/S are capable of seeing different things. Sometimes something that shows up on the mammo doesn't show on the U/S, and vice-versa.  MRIs find all sorts of things and are notorious for "false positives." Recently my obgyn, who's about 60 and has been at this for many years, told me she has never had a patient for which something relevant was found on an MRI that hadn't been seen on mammo or U/S. She actually counsels her patients against having breast MRIs. However, there have been women on this forum whose BC was only found by MRI, so obviously it does help some percentage of women. Regarding biopsies: to the best of my knowledge (which may be incorrect), biopsies are guided either by mammo, U/S, or MRI. Mine was mammo-guided. It seems to me, guineamom, if one of the lesions visible on the mammo was not visible on the U/S, then a mammo ought to have been used to guide the biopsy. Assuming that you do indeed have dense breasts, as the radiologist said, this does apparently present a particular problem in radiology. For example, I do not have dense breasts, and the areas of concern show up very nicely, as whiter areas, on my mammos and U/Ss. Apparently if one has dense breasts everything looks white. Therefore the areas of concern are harder to identify. As I say, however, it seems to me that if they can see an area of concern via imaging method "A" but not via imaging method "B," they ought to use method A to do the biopsy. Do be aware that having MRIs is not without health risks. The MRI itself is harmless, but generally a contrast medium is delivered intravenously during the MRI, and there are some risks associated with the use of the contrast medium. Most people who have a handful of MRIs with contrast during their lives will be just fine, but it's not the sort of thing one ought to go through every day.

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 05:31PM cycle-path wrote: While you should definitely see a specialist about your lump, do be aware that the vast majority of breast lumps are not cancerous. The odds of this being cancer are quite low. Most painful lumps are not cancer (though there are exceptions to that), so you have many reasons to be optimistic about what you'll eventually learn. The diagram below shows the odds of being diagnosed with cancer, so you can see how unusual it is.  And, in addition to there being fairly low odds of being diagnosed with cancer, please note that 80% of the breast cancers found are early stage and very treatable. Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2011 06:29PM cycle-path wrote: LWA, there are no extremely long term statistics on IORT, but please understand that it is not the same as brachytherapy for a number of reasons. The most important of those reasons is this: tissue that is under surgical manipulation has a rich vascularization, which makes it more sensitive to the action of the radiation. Brachytherapy doesn't have that same benefit.  Another important difference is that with IORT, the radiation is delivered to the cavity before any stray tumor cells have a chance to get out and spread. As Jelson says above, comparing IORT to brachytheraphy is an apples to oranges comparison. Of course the decision is yours, but IMO you won't regret it. My surgery with IORT was 11 months ago and I'm still thankful I was able to have it.

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2011 01:03PM cycle-path wrote: Here's an article about the doctors rebutting the findings of the brachytherapy study. It sounds to me as though the study was quite poorly designed. The main points in the article were: 1. The study is flawed in that: a) The data did not report cancer-recurrence rates. b) The study states that mastectomy rates equate to recurrence rates, which is not true. c) The reported complication rates are unrealistically high and differ dramatically from better-done studies in scientific literature. 2. Patients now have access to newer and better forms of APBI that have been developed since the Medicare data was created. The MDA study was based on Medicare billing claims for more than 130,000 patients over the age of 66 who were diagnosed with early-stage breast cancer between 2000 and 2007 and received a lumpectomy and radiation. Researchers observed an increase of 1.8 percent in the rate of mastectomies among women who received breast brachytherapy. The older, "balloon" form of brachytherapy covered by the data was also associated with somewhat higher toxicity and complication rates. "Among several shortcomings of the San Antonio study data," said Dr. Kuske, is the fact that it covers "an antiquated balloon catheter with a single channel. Since that time, technology has dramatically improved to encompass the use of newer, multichannel applicators. The side effects and toxicity seen with these modern technological advances are far less than the results presented in the study."  The three major medical societies involved in the research and use of APBI have also issued statements of concern about the study conclusions.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 09:31PM cycle-path wrote: "The intraoperative is done during surgery when you have the lumpectomey. This techniques is very new and very few hospitals/radiologists offer this treatment at this time." Actually, interoperative radiation therapy (IORT) is not new. It was first used in 1905 -- back then external beam radiation therapy couldn't reach deep tumors. However, it's true that it isn't very widely available in the US. In Europe, though, it's one of the preferred ways to treat breast cancer. The main reason it's not used as much here is that radiation oncologists don't make as much money from IORT as they make from external beam.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2011 11:54PM - edited Nov 1, 2011 11:56PM by cycle-path I agree with you that surgery for a benign lesion seems a little odd for your mom considering her age and other health issues, and it's certainly something to talk to the surgeon about. It wouldn't surprise me too much if the surgeon thinks it's ok to leave it. Surgery carries risks, and there are greater risks for older people and those with other health problems. That being said, a lumpectomy is really fairly minor surgery if no lymph nodes are being removed. So if she does have the surgery done, your sister and she may find that it's really not a big deal. Many women sail right through it, though of course most are many years younger.  Lumpectomies are usually done under general anesthesia, but on the BCO boards we often hear from a woman who had hers under local anesthetic and some sort of "light general" or "twilight sleep" such as Versed. Be sure your sister asks the surgeon about this.

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2011 05:45PM cycle-path wrote: Although I have both my kidneys, I often recommend that others look into the type of radiation I had, which is called Intraoperative Radiation Therapy (IORT). You get only one dose of radiation right in the tumor bed, and there's a much lower possibility of radiation "scatter" with this method. So internal organs (heart, lungs, ribs) are generally better protected. There's also no possibility of radiation "sunburn." You can learn about this type of radiation at http://www.breastcanceriort.org/

I don't think I included any in which women got broken ribs after radiation, Shingles, or heart problems, but those too are possible SEs from WBI. By contrast, the SEs from Mammosite are discomfort with the balloon while it's in place, and the possibility of a seroma (not a true cyst). Seromas can happen with any type of breast surgery, whether or not there's radiation, but develop somewhat more commonly with Mammosite-type radiation. Give me seromas over broken ribs, shingles, or pleurisy any day of the week!

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 09:33PM cycle-path wrote: Here's what the report says: You have a rather large, high grade ductal carcinoma in situ, and next to the large noninvasive tumor there's a very small invasive tumor. The large tumor  has good estrogen receptors and fairly good progestone receptors. You didn't give the estrogen Allred score for the small invasive tumor but its progestone receptors are the same as that of the DCIS. Here's what it means: you have a fairly garden-variety, non-invasive tumor called DCIS. As you already know, the docs want to remove it, and the small invasive tumor, with surgery.  If a mastectomy is done, there may be no need for radiation. Because the small tumor is invasive, the doc will want to do more tests. It's possible, though not terribly likely, that some chemotherapy will be suggested. Probably an estrogen suppressing medication will be prescribed, such as Tamoxifen. As I said, this is a pretty garden-variety early tumor and pretty easily treatable. It's something that needs to be taken care of, but it's not something particularly dangerous as long as the treatments are completed. Here's what you need to understand: You're not on the Titanic. You're not circling the drain. Although you have breast cancer, you are not Elizabeth Edwards. You have something quite treatable, and she did not. About the pain you have: You're going through something that's traumatic to you, as it should be. The reason you still have pain is almost certainly because of the anguish you're feeling. Please take care of yourself, as you are going to need some mental and physical strength to get through surgery and recovery. When I was diagnosed, my BS gave me info about support groups I could join and places I could go if I felt I needed talk therapy. Have any of the doctors provided any such info to you? They really ought to. On Monday, call whichever doctor you've been dealing with and tell them you need help dealing with the emotional aspects of your diagnosis. Don't try to tough it out and don't ignore the signals your body is giving you. Sometimes when your mind is in pain it inflicts pain on your body, and that's almost certainly what's causing you to feel pain from your biopsy. Please do take care of yourself.

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2011 11:07AM - edited Dec 21, 2011 11:49AM by cycle-path Eileen, I've wondered about this as well and what I've come to understand is that there's no such thing as "THE" sentinel lymph node. There are several, though the medical literature refers to "the first SLN" and "the second SLN" and so forth. A study a few years ago showed that the optimal number of nodes to remove is two. When only one is harvested, only 87.9% of nodal invasions are found. When two are harvested, 97% are found. The third raises the number to nearly 100%. If you've been reading BCO for a while, you may have seen that on very rare occasions the surgeon finds no invasion in any sentinel node but the cancer is later found to have metastasized. Somehow it got past the first couple of nodes undetected and into the lymphatic system. However, as I say this is apparently quite rare.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2011 12:15PM cycle-path wrote: A well-differentiated cell is a normal cell. Moderately differentiated is a cell that's started to morph into something else, and a poorly differentiated cell is one that's totally wacked out.  Basically, cancer cells are regular cells that started doing crazy stuff. It's like they're doing drugs. The moderately differentiated ones are just smoking pot -- a little wacky, but not totally strange. The poorly differentiated ones are the meth heads -- totally strange. Ductal means it's in the mild ducts. Some breast cancers are ductal and some are lobular (in the milk lobes) and some are something else, but the majority are either in the ducts or lobes.

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2011 07:52PM cycle-path wrote: While I'm not positive about this, I believe there are 2 kinds of clear margins. There's the margins in which there's no cancer, and then there's the margins in which there's not even any ADH or ALH.  Maybe someone else can give more info about whether "clear" means hyperplasia free.  The reason it might make a difference is this. Let's say you have a tumor that's exactly 1 cm and perfectly round, and it's right in the middle of a round area that's ADH. The tumor and the ADH together measure a total of 3 cm.  So let's say they take both out and there's a margin of only 1 mm. They got all the tumor plus 1.1 cm of tissue with no tumor, but they only got 1 mm of non-ADH tissue. So what are the margins? 1.1 cm or 1 mm?

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2012 10:48PM cycle-path wrote: I think something like a weekly pill box is a perfectly fine thing, and in fact I've used one for years. But if a researcher thinks it's going to make a difference in getting someone to take a pill that makes her ill, well, then.... Well, I'm not going to say what I think should happen to that researcher but believe me it's not a pleasant fate. Here's the reason women are non-compliant with Tamoxifen. We're told that if we take it for 1825 days it "might" keep us from getting something that we "might" get. We don't know we'll get BC again if we don't take it. We don't know we'll be protected from BC if we do. It only reduces risk -- and in many cases the risk is already pretty small -- by half. And we have to take it for a long time to get that dubious benefit. Oh, and BTW, most women get at least some SEs, however minor, from it! But that report seems to think that telling us to use a little pill box is going to make a difference! Once again, I won't say what I really think of a person who gives such advice and will settle for the term MORONIC! If there were no SEs, women would be willing to put up with the uncertainty of whether Tamoxifen made a difference. Or if there was certainty -- if one could be guaranteed that BC wouldn't come back if one took it -- more women would put up with SEs. THAT'S the problem. It's a pure risk/reward scenario. Too much risk, too little assurance of reward. Instead of giving this problem to medical folks to analyze, it ought to be looked at by MBA candidates, who learn about this when they study asset rates of return!

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2011 08:49AM cycle-path wrote: Etherize: please email your friend back and tell her my story. Four days after Elizabeth Edwards died of breast cancer, I found out I had it too. Fortunately, thanks to a mammogram, a non-palpable tumor was found. In a few weeks I had surgery to remove the tumor and internal radiation.  Without a mammo I wouldn't have known about this very early, very curable cancer. I ended up with a small scar on one breast (which should fade to near invisibility), no chemo, and no disfigurement. None. If you want to PM me, I'll even send you pictures to prove how minor the surgery was. The difference between me and Elizabeth Edwards is that mine was found early when only a mammo would detect it. I ended up with a small fading scar and, essentially, a cure. Hers was found late and she died. Mammos are what can give you the GOOD outcomes. No mammos has the possibility of giving you the BAD outcomes. Your friend has a choice: she can be me, or she can be Elizabeth Edwards. She should opt for the likelihood of a GOOD outcome and get the annual mammo. (Regarding concern about radiation: though you think it's bogus, she can discuss that issue with her doc ask that she get an ultrasound instead. Ultrasound is also sometimes also used as a first-line breast diagnostic tool.)

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2011 01:58PM cycle-path wrote: So many of us are in the "getting old is not for sissies" stage of life! In my view, there's a big difference between pancreatic cancer and the stage 1 BC you had. The prognosis for pancreatic cancer is very poor, while the prognosis for a small stage 1 BC is excellent. I think comparing them is a little like comparing pneumonia to a chest cold -- they're just not the same. Yes, both are cancer, but IMO that's where the similarity ends.  I think assisted living can be great. One of my mom's friends went to live in a 3 stage senior community -- the first stage was a condo with access to community dining and so forth, the second stage was more of an assisted living small apartment, and the third stage was skilled nursing. She went comfortably through all 3 stages and it was terrific for her.   So while a senior community is a wonderful option, I had thought you might want to get some kind of professional help with your anxiety sooner.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2012 06:52PM cycle-path wrote: Well, an ultrasound by itself isn't painful, and "stereotactic" basically means they do the biopsy while your breast is in the mammogram device. So if you find a mammo to be painful, you might find being held in place during the stereotactic biopsy to be painful. In either case, though, you'll get a few shots of lidocaine to numb you before they take the tissue. The most painful part of that is the shot itself. I didn't find it painful -- it's described as being "like a bee sting" but I've been stung by bees and I think a bee sting is far worse. If they're doing a lot of biopsies there's a pretty good chance you'll be sore afterward, but with some Advil or Motrin or the like, and an ice pack, you'll be fine.

One reason is what kind of equipment a particular doctor has and what his or her expertise is. But there are more important reasons. If a lesion is visible on mammo but not on ultrasound, then of course the biopsy must be done during a mammo. And the reverse is also true. Furthermore, there are some lesions that aren't easily reached -- a lesion very near the chest wall may be more difficult to biopsy with one method than with another.
